recipes: In times of especial crisis, I might visit a discreet pharmacist, to purchase a tincture of opium and make my dreams sweet. But only in times of especial crisis. [This is an expensive and risky way to gain Contentment.]
Oh, that deep peace. But I should not do this again.

Sometimes, I have dreamt of a tall woman in a sand-coloured coat, who stands at the foot of my bed, smiling as she watches me sleep. In that dream, she turns her head with the swiftness of a bird, and her fingers flex like talons. I do not think I dreamt of her last night. If I had, I could not have slept so soundly.
I have gone some time without food. I should eat carefully.
My strength returns. The wheeling dark at the corners of my sight is gone.
The medicine is dark and bitter as tar. It would be easy to suspect I am being poisoned.
The sick-room grows close and stale. Time to get up.
All I need now is time.
The sick-room grows close and stale. Time to get up.
I remember that I was different: but I no longer remember how.
I remember that I was different, before.
The sun still moves. The wind still walks. My journals are the labyrinth clue.
The doors of vision have cracked open. Perhaps I should calm myself, somehow. Even Dread has its uses.
A little darkness will mellow my light; a little ballast will bring me back to earth.
The air is curdled now. I am home again, in this lumpen flesh. Better, perhaps.
